Hopkins Attacked For Urban Avail,
By BRUCE DRAKE
Civil rights and community-action leaders have
thargecl that Hopkins has taken a "disgraceful" stand
On racial isues and has "turned its back on Baltimore."
Both the administration and student body were
scored for their lack of involvement with the problems of Baltimore. Hopkin's relatively new policy of
recruiting more Negro students was also criticized as
being a token effort.
Activists critical of the University included: Walter
Brooks, Baltimore director of the Congress for Racial
Equality; Bill Henry, director of the Baltimore Tutorial Projects; Maryland Senator Julian Lapides; and
Reverend Robert Meissner, a long-time participant in
community-action projects.
Hopkins Image"Poor"
Senator Lapides felt that in the area of civil rights,
Hopkins' image was "quite poor." He added that
"Hopkins must take the initiative in this field."
Walter Brooks charged that "it is inexcusable for any
institution of Hopkins' size not to address itself to
the most crucial problems of the times." He stressed
the role of Hopkins should be a "creator and pusher."
Hopkins was severely attacked for its lack of partiSipation in the community. Senator Lapides described
Hopkins as being "aloof from the city and neighborhood problems," and that the University has erected
an "artificial wall" between itself and the community.

Reverend Meissner stated that Hopkins must "come
those
to grips," with city problems and should help
the
"struggling out in the community." He added that
conUniversity is only a "parasite" if it doesn't make
tributions to help overcome Baltimore's problems.
Could Help Educational Mess
Hopkins could be a crucial factor in

Henry said further that Hopkins could do great
re-good if it would throw its financial and academic
sources behind projects like Headstart and Upward
Bound, a pre-college educational program. He added
that Hopkins, as an established and prestigious institution, could easily get federal grants to boost educational projects throughout the city, especially for the
economically deprived with whom the Baltimore Tutorial Project is concerned. Not only would Hopkins aid
many understaffed and underfinanced agencies, but
that it would "legitimize its stand as a leading educational institution."

Henry's main complaint, however, was with Hopkins students. He charged that they are "more than
apathetic." Out of the 200 students who helped the
tutorial project this past year, he said, only ten have
come from Hopkins, the largest college in the • city.
Both Reverend Meissner and Henry expressed the feeling that the Hopkins student, who has the opportunity
to acquire the best intellectual benefits, should share
these benefits with those who are more deprived.
A main topic in the attack on Hopkins concerned
housing. Brooks stressed the need for institutions like
Hopkins to throw support behind progressive housing
policies, inferring that initiative now will prevent
social problems later. He warned that if the Federal
government doesn't provide massive aid, and if institutions like Hopkins don't begin a push for improvement, then the deprived Negroes would have no choice
but to "burn, baby, burn."
University "Scared"
On issues such as housing, Henry said that prestigious people at Hopkins "should be man enough to
stand up and talk" about crucial problems. Most of
Hopkins critics strongly implied that the University
has been scared to take stands on issues surrounded
by controversy. Senator Lapides underscored this feeling by saying that it should be natural for Hopkins
to be an initiator in controversial and critical areas.

President Of Morgan
Censors Newspaper

Campus Notes

Dr. Martin Jenkins, president
of Morgan State College, suspended publication of the
school paper, the Spokesman on
April 2. Dr. Jenkins stated that
the reason for the suspension
was the appearance of too many
"typographical errors." Kenny
Smothers, editor-in-chief of the
Spokesman, was to have discussed the issue with Dr. Jenkins
last Wednesday.
News Editor Thomas Dantoni
charged that the actual reason
for the suspension was the administration's anger at the April
Fools' day edition which criticized Dr. Jenkins and his administration. The suspension

The article also criticized the
student refectory. This was a follow-up to the boycott of the student cafeteria which was staged
last semester to protest the poor
quality of the food.

The Wilson College Choir and
the Hopkins Glee Club will gleefully present a combined concert
on Sunday, April 16, at 8:30 in
Shriver Hall.

Faculty—Student Hour
Dr. Francis Rourke, Chairman of the Political Science
Department, will be present
at the faculty-student coffee
hour April 20 at 4 p.m. in the
Sherwood Room of Levering
Hail. Coffee and donuts will
be served.

War and Peace
The Student Association is
sponsoring two Viet Nam documentaries on April 17 at 7:30
p.m. in the Great Hall. Featured
will be "Why Vietnam," produced by the U.S. Department
of Defense and "Sons and
Daughters," a film about the
anti-war movement at Berkeley.
Admission will be free.

Passover Meals

Mixer Follows

Calling All Milk Maids
All girls who are high school
graduates, between 18 and 25,
single, and live—or have lived—
on a dairy farm are invited to
enter the 1967 Maryland Dairy
Princess Contest. The deadline
for entering is May 1st. Contact
Mr. James Breon, Atlantic Dairy
Association, Box 102, Randal'stown 21133.

Cria Cria
The Committee to Rescue
Italian Art will feature pianist
Deno Gianopoulos in a Shriver
Hall Concert, on Tuesday, April
25 at 8:30 p.m. Gianopoulos recently played for Princess Irene
of Greece on her musical tour
of the United States.

The Kosher Dining Club will
be serving Passover meals for the
eight-day holiday to all interested Jewish students, both
graduate and undergraduate.
Passover begins on the evening of April 24 and ends May
2. Two Seders will be held on the
evenings of the 24th and the
25th. In addition, dinners and
lunches will be served daily. The
Seders will be conducted by
guest Rabbis.
The cost for each Seder will
be $3, dinners will be $2, and
lunches will cost $1.50. Interested
persons should contact either
David Roodman, Box 632, or
Dennis Estis, Box 2128.

Poli Scil Honors
Pi Sigma Alpha, the Political
Science Honor Society, is accepting applications from Juniors and Seniors with ten credits
in Political Science and a B
average. Box 144.

Vault Pit
Dama t ed
By Arsons
Four young arsonists are believed to have started a fire
which caused almost the complete destruction of the pole
vault pit used by the Hopkins
track team.
The fire which occurred last
Wednesday afternoon at Homewood Field required the speedy
attention of three hook and ladder trucks and over 25 firemen
and investigators. Billowing black
smoke enveloped the entire field
and could be seen for miles in
the surrounding area.
An early estimate of the total
damage, reached as high as $600.
Marshall Turner, director of athletics, believed that the school's
insurance covered such an incident.
Alexander Davidoff, a senior
Psychology major, was on the
field at the time; and he observed
four boys, 18 or 19 years old,
moving about the field; fooling
around behind the stands with
the phone booth; and standing
around the pole vault pit.
He did not see them actually
set the fire; but minutes before
the blaze began, Davidoff observed the four youths climbing
over the fence on university
Parkway near the vaulting area,
One of the arsonists was ob,
served to be holding a can of
beer; another was said to have
been wearing a turtle neck sweat-,
er; and a third had a green beret
on his head.

The foam rubber which comprises the landing area of the pit
suffered the greatest damage. It
was necessary for the firemen to
take it completely apart in order
to put out all the little smoldering pieces of rubber.
Police and Fire Department
investigating teams were inunediately dispatched to the scene
of the crime. Cars were sent
throughout the area near the
University In the hope of finding
the culprits. As of Thursday. they
had not been apprehended.
Turner said that nothing like
this had ever happened before,
and it would take some time before repairs could be completed.
"Everything will have to be
pulled back together again," he
stated.

Miss Davis detailed the history
of the grading system at Hopkins. In the 1920's, she said, Hopkins had a grade-point system of
6 to 10. This was replaced in 1930
by a system including the grades
of Honors, Satisfactory, and Fail
for the School of Arts and Sciences. Due to pressure from the
graduate schools this system was
replaced in 1938 by grades of
H, A, B, C, D, E, F. The E was
soon dropped because of its misuse as a grade rather than as a
conditional failure. In 1962 the
H was dropped, since only 11
/
2
per cent of the students were
earning it, causing those earning
A's to be discriminated against
by graduate schools.
Dr. Geen described the new
Pass-Fail option recently instituted at Goucher after a series
of student-faculty reports. The

Dr. Geen said that this system,
now in its second term of a twoyear experimental period, was
working "fairly well", despite the
fact that some students abused
it.
Dr. Diermann, commenting on
the prospects of instituting a
pass-fail system of some sort
here at Hopkins, said that while
no one on the Committee for
Undergraduate Affairs is specifically opposed to pass-fail in
some form, additional studies on
the subject must be made. He
said that further discussion on
the administrative level would
have to wait until Dean Swanson
returned from his sabbatical in
September.

After dropping their season
opener to Randolph-Macon last
Saturday, the varsity tennis
squad hopes to gain its first
home victory tomorrow against
Swarthmore at 12 o'clock.
Hosting the Yellow Jackets of
Randolph - Macon, the J a y
dropped a well-played match to
a team which had already participated in nine contests. Coach
Tom McDermott was quite satisfied with his charges, stating that
"they appeared in excellent
shape and made a good Showing." The Jays forced three of
the seven matches to go for three
sets. The remaining four sets
went into extra games. They
dropped the contest, nonetheless,
2-5.
Sophs Lead
Sophomores Art Guerin, Mike
Marcus, and Nabby Bronstein
lead the contingent. Most of last
year's group had been lost via
graduation, leaving Coach McDermott with the up-and-coming
sophomores.
Guerin, "the number one
man," stopped Ned Kurtis of
Randolph-Macon 3-6, 6-3, 6-2;
meanwhile Marcus handed Charlie Sherod a 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 defeat
in a dramatic "comeback" match.
Bronstein, who played quite well
before receiving a leg injury, lost
in extra games to Metz of Randolph-Macon.
Coach McDermott considers
the Swarthmore contest tomorrow "the rubber match of the
season." Swarthmore is "one of
the teams to beat" and has
bested Army and Navy in the
past. The match tomorrow will
begin at 12 noon.

Hopkins Attacked For Urban Avail,
By BRUCE DRAKE
Civil rights and community-action leaders have
thargecl that Hopkins has taken a "disgraceful" stand
On racial isues and has "turned its back on Baltimore."
Both the administration and student body were
scored for their lack of involvement with the problems of Baltimore. Hopkin's relatively new policy of
recruiting more Negro students was also criticized as
being a token effort.
Activists critical of the University included: Walter
Brooks, Baltimore director of the Congress for Racial
Equality; Bill Henry, director of the Baltimore Tutorial Projects; Maryland Senator Julian Lapides; and
Reverend Robert Meissner, a long-time participant in
community-action projects.
Hopkins Image"Poor"
Senator Lapides felt that in the area of civil rights,
Hopkins' image was "quite poor." He added that
"Hopkins must take the initiative in this field."
Walter Brooks charged that "it is inexcusable for any
institution of Hopkins' size not to address itself to
the most crucial problems of the times." He stressed
the role of Hopkins should be a "creator and pusher."
Hopkins was severely attacked for its lack of partiSipation in the community. Senator Lapides described
Hopkins as being "aloof from the city and neighborhood problems," and that the University has erected
an "artificial wall" between itself and the community.

Reverend Meissner stated that Hopkins must "come
those
to grips," with city problems and should help
the
"struggling out in the community." He added that
conUniversity is only a "parasite" if it doesn't make
tributions to help overcome Baltimore's problems.

Henry said further that Hopkins could do great
re-good if it would throw its financial and academic
sources behind projects like Headstart and Upward
Bound, a pre-college educational program. He added
that Hopkins, as an established and prestigious institution, could easily get federal grants to boost educational projects throughout the city, especially for the
economically deprived with whom the Baltimore Tutorial Project is concerned. Not only would Hopkins aid
many understaffed and underfinanced agencies, but
that it would "legitimize its stand as a leading educational institution."

Henry's main complaint, however, was with Hopkins students. He charged that they are "more than
apathetic." Out of the 200 students who helped the
tutorial project this past year, he said, only ten have
come from Hopkins, the largest college in the • city.
Both Reverend Meissner and Henry expressed the feeling that the Hopkins student, who has the opportunity
to acquire the best intellectual benefits, should share
these benefits with those who are more deprived.
A main topic in the attack on Hopkins concerned
housing. Brooks stressed the need for institutions like
Hopkins to throw support behind progressive housing
policies, inferring that initiative now will prevent
social problems later. He warned that if the Federal
government doesn't provide massive aid, and if institutions like Hopkins don't begin a push for improvement, then the deprived Negroes would have no choice
but to "burn, baby, burn."
University "Scared"
On issues such as housing, Henry said that prestigious people at Hopkins "should be man enough to
stand up and talk" about crucial problems. Most of
Hopkins critics strongly implied that the University
has been scared to take stands on issues surrounded
by controversy. Senator Lapides underscored this feeling by saying that it should be natural for Hopkins
to be an initiator in controversial and critical areas.

Vault Pit
Dama t ed
By Arsons
Four young arsonists are believed to have started a fire
which caused almost the complete destruction of the pole
vault pit used by the Hopkins
track team.
The fire which occurred last
Wednesday afternoon at Homewood Field required the speedy
attention of three hook and ladder trucks and over 25 firemen
and investigators. Billowing black
smoke enveloped the entire field
and could be seen for miles in
the surrounding area.
An early estimate of the total
damage, reached as high as $600.
Marshall Turner, director of athletics, believed that the school's
insurance covered such an incident.
Alexander Davidoff, a senior
Psychology major, was on the
field at the time; and he observed
four boys, 18 or 19 years old,
moving about the field; fooling
around behind the stands with
the phone booth; and standing
around the pole vault pit.
He did not see them actually
set the fire; but minutes before
the blaze began, Davidoff observed the four youths climbing
over the fence on university
Parkway near the vaulting area,
One of the arsonists was ob,
served to be holding a can of
beer; another was said to have
been wearing a turtle neck sweat-,
er; and a third had a green beret
on his head.

The foam rubber which comprises the landing area of the pit
suffered the greatest damage. It
was necessary for the firemen to
take it completely apart in order
to put out all the little smoldering pieces of rubber.
Police and Fire Department
investigating teams were inunediately dispatched to the scene
of the crime. Cars were sent
throughout the area near the
University In the hope of finding
the culprits. As of Thursday. they
had not been apprehended.
Turner said that nothing like
this had ever happened before,
and it would take some time before repairs could be completed.
"Everything will have to be
pulled back together again," he
stated.

Miss Davis detailed the history
of the grading system at Hopkins. In the 1920's, she said, Hopkins had a grade-point system of
6 to 10. This was replaced in 1930
by a system including the grades
of Honors, Satisfactory, and Fail
for the School of Arts and Sciences. Due to pressure from the
graduate schools this system was
replaced in 1938 by grades of
H, A, B, C, D, E, F. The E was
soon dropped because of its misuse as a grade rather than as a
conditional failure. In 1962 the
H was dropped, since only 11
/
2
per cent of the students were
earning it, causing those earning
A's to be discriminated against
by graduate schools.
Dr. Geen described the new
Pass-Fail option recently instituted at Goucher after a series
of student-faculty reports. The

Dr. Geen said that this system,
now in its second term of a twoyear experimental period, was
working "fairly well", despite the
fact that some students abused
it.
Dr. Diermann, commenting on
the prospects of instituting a
pass-fail system of some sort
here at Hopkins, said that while
no one on the Committee for
Undergraduate Affairs is specifically opposed to pass-fail in
some form, additional studies on
the subject must be made. He
said that further discussion on
the administrative level would
have to wait until Dean Swanson
returned from his sabbatical in
September.

After dropping their season
opener to Randolph-Macon last
Saturday, the varsity tennis
squad hopes to gain its first
home victory tomorrow against
Swarthmore at 12 o'clock.
Hosting the Yellow Jackets of
Randolph - Macon, the J a y
dropped a well-played match to
a team which had already participated in nine contests. Coach
Tom McDermott was quite satisfied with his charges, stating that
"they appeared in excellent
shape and made a good Showing." The Jays forced three of
the seven matches to go for three
sets. The remaining four sets
went into extra games. They
dropped the contest, nonetheless,
2-5.
Sophs Lead
Sophomores Art Guerin, Mike
Marcus, and Nabby Bronstein
lead the contingent. Most of last
year's group had been lost via
graduation, leaving Coach McDermott with the up-and-coming

man," stopped Ned Kurtis of
Randolph-Macon 3-6, 6-3, 6-2;
meanwhile Marcus handed Charlie Sherod a 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 defeat
in a dramatic "comeback" match.
Bronstein, who played quite well
before receiving a leg injury, lost
in extra games to Metz of Randolph-Macon.
Coach McDermott considers
the Swarthmore contest tomorrow "the rubber match of the
season." Swarthmore is "one of
the teams to beat" and has
bested Army and Navy in the
past. The match tomorrow will
begin at 12 noon.

Bob Scott, "a threat to anybody

Coach Gene Corrigan's attack
crew, which often tries to set up
plays around the crease area,
consists of seniors Bill Harrison
and John Boyce and sophomore
Pete Kirk, none of whom appears
to be an offensive threat of any
huge stature. This threesome,
however, was highly praised by
Jay scouts for its ball handling
and capacity to maintain offensive control.
Two Strong Midfields —
The midfield contingent, whose
first two units Scott calls "as
good as any we've seen so far"
and which plays a major role in
Cavalier offensive efforts, includes a first group of seniors
Frank Buck and Terry Horner (a

good faceoff man), who team

second, staffed by soph Frank
Quayle (Outstanding Back in the
Atlantic Coast Conference last
fall and probably the top Cavalier middle), senior John Ashworth, and soph Tad Joerdens.
Top operator on the defense,
which has allowed but seven
goals in two collegiate encounters, is 5-10, 167 pound Pete Coy,
termed a fast and very aggressive
performer by team scouting reports. He is joined by two sizable
seniors-5-10, 200 pound Ridge
Warfield and 5-11. 200 pound
